Federated Learning from Heterogeneous Data via Controlled Bayesian Air Aggregation

Tomer Gafni, Kobi Cohen, Yonina C. Eldar T. Gafni and K. Cohen are with the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel (e-mail:gafnito@post.bgu.ac.il; yakovsec@bgu.ac.il). Yonina C. Eldar is with the Math and CS Faculty, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel (e-mail: yonina.eldar@weizmann.ac.il). This work was supported by the Israel Science Foundation under Grant 2640/20. A short version of this paper that introduces the COBAAF algorithm, and preliminary simulation results was presented in Proceedings of the 58th Annual Allerton Conference on Communication, Control, and Computing (Allerton) [1]. In this journal version we include: (i) A detailed discussion on the implementation of the BAAF and COBAAF algorithms; (ii) a deep theoretical analysis of the algorithms with detailed proofs; (iii) more extensive simulation results; and (iv) a detailed discussion of the results, and comprehensive discussion and comparison with the existing literature.
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging machine learning paradigm for training models across multiple edge devices holding local data sets, without explicitly exchanging the data. Recently, over-the-air (OTA) FL has been suggested to reduce the bandwidth and energy consumption, by allowing the users to transmit their data simultaneously over a Multiple Access Channel (MAC). However, this approach results in channel noise directly affecting the optimization procedure, which may degrade the accuracy of the trained model. In this paper we jointly exploit the prior distribution of local weights and the channel distribution, and develop an OTA FL algorithm based on a Bayesian approach for signal aggregation. Our proposed algorithm, dubbed Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated learning (BAAF), is shown to effectively mitigate noise and fading effects induced by the channel. To handle statistical heterogeneity of users data, which is a second major challenge in FL, we extend BAAF to allow for appropriate local updates by the users and develop the Controlled Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated-learning (COBAAF) algorithm. In addition to using a Bayesian approach to average the channel output, COBAAF controls the drift in local updates using a judicious design of correction terms. We analyze the convergence of the learned global model using BAAF and COBAAF in noisy and heterogeneous environment, showing their ability to achieve a convergence rate similar to that achieved over error-free channels. Simulation results demonstrate the improved convergence of BAAF and COBAAF over existing algorithms in machine learning tasks.

I Introduction

In recent years, machine learning algorithms have given rise to advances in multiple fields, such as natural language processing, computer vision, and speech recognition [2]. Since these algorithms are data driven, their success hinges on vast amounts of training data. Nowadays, a lot of this data is generated on edge devices such as mobile phones, sensors, vehicles, and medical devices. The common strategy is to gather these samples at a computationally powerful server, which uses them to train its model [3]. Due to privacy and locality concerns, uploading of data sets, such as images and text messages, may be undesirable. Furthermore, the communication link between edge devices and the server can be heavily burdened by sharing of massive data sets.

These difficulties can be tackled by exploiting the increased computational power of mobile devices via mobile edge computing, in which training and inference is performed directly at network edges without having to share the raw data. In such systems, learning from distributed data and communicating between the edge server and devices are two critical and coupled aspects. This motivates the edge learning framework of federated learning (FL), which features distributed learning at edge devices with centralized aggregations, orchestrated by an edge server, and is the focus of growing research attention over the last few years [4, 5, 6]. The fact that the complete data set is not available to the server leads to several core challenges that are not encountered in conventional machine learning methods. In this paper we focus on two of the main challenges in FL: Noise induced by the shared channel due to the communication bottleneck, and statistical heterogeneity of users’ data.

The communication bottleneck in FL arises from the need for a large number of users to repeatedly and concurrently send their intermediate learned models (e.g., deep neural networks weights) to the server over shared and resource-limited wireless networks. A commonly adopted strategy to tackle this challenge is to model the wireless channel as a set of independent error-free bit-limited links between the users and the server, e.g., by using frequency division multiplexing (FDM), and then to apply methods of compressing the conveyed model parameters via quantization [7, 8, 9] or sparsification [10, 11]. This, however, results in each user being assigned a dedicated bandwidth which decreases with the number of participating users, increasing the energy consumption required to meet a desirable communication rate, and decreasing in the overall throughput and training speed. An alternative approach is to allow the users to simultaneously utilize the complete temporal and spectral resources of the uplink Multiple Access Channel (MAC) in a non-orthogonal manner, and in this way exploit the inherent aggregation carried out by the shared channel as a form of over-the-air (OTA) computation [12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18].

Recently, OTA has been studied in the FL context [19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27]. This approach allows each transmitter to utilize the complete available channel resources, e.g., bandwidth, regardless of the number of users. However, this results in channel noise directly affecting the model weights. This may degrade the accuracy of the trained model as SGD is known to be sensitive to noisy observations [28]. In [20], the authors considered scenario where the model updates are sparse with an identical sparsity pattern, which is not likely to hold when the data is heterogeneous. In [29, 30], the authors used a Bayesian aggregation procedure to handle the channel noise and fading. However, they considered distributed application of full gradient descent optimization over noisy channels with a single local step at each round, which is less efficient in terms of communication and computation resources as compared to FedAvg.

In our previous work, we proposed the COTAF algorithm [31] which facilitates high throughput FL over wireless channels, while preserving the convergence properties of the common FedAvg method for distributed learning, by introducing a time-varying precoding at the users. While COTAF has demonstrated some success in handling noise, in this work we take an additional step towards better noise reduction. By exploiting the prior distribution of local weights and the channel distribution, we address the noise challenge in OTA FL using a Bayesian approach, introducing the Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated-learning (BAAF) algorithm. Similarly to previous OTA FL methods, BAAF utilizes the fact that the model updates in FL are typically transmitted to be averaged, and uses OTA transmissions for increasing the throughput when operating over a shared channel. The transmission is then judiciously designed such that the received noisy signal at the server follows a Bayesian combining strategy. Specifically, we jointly exploit the distribution of the local models and the communication channels when aggregating the noisy local models received by the server, and estimate the noise-free sum of local models. Under the premise that the prior distributions of the local models are jointly Gaussian and the channel is Gaussian with block fading, this aggregation method is optimal in the sense of minimizing the mean-squared error (MSE) per communication round.

We analyze theoretically the convergence of models trained by BAAF, when the objective is a strongly convex and smooth function with bounded gradients, as commonly assumed for purposes of theoretical analysis in FL convergence studies [32, 33]. We rigorously show the effect of our MMSE estimation on the convergence of the algorithm compared to FedAvg that assumed noise-free and fading-free channels, and show superior theoretical performance over [31] in handling the noise under the same statistical model. Specifically, BAAF achieves the same convergence rate as FedAvg, with an additional noise term which depends on the MSE of our aggregation strategy and decays as 1/R1𝑅1/R, where R𝑅R is the number of communication rounds. We show explicitly that our error term convergences to zero with a higher rate compared to the corresponding term in [31]. We also analyze the performance of BAAF numerically, and demonstrate its improved performance over conventional OTA FL and over the COTAF algorithm.

Our second contribution is the extension of our results to FL with statistical heterogeneity among users’ data sets. Statistical heterogeneity implies that the data generating distributions vary among different sets of users [32]. This is often the case in FL, as the data available at each user’s device is likely to be personalized. Statistical heterogeneity implies that when training several instances of a model on multiple edge devices, each instance may be biased. While FedAvg [4] is a very popular algorithm for FL, implementing it on heterogeneous data results in slow and unstable convergence due to the drift in the local updates. Several solutions have been suggested to address statistical heterogeneity, such as adding a regularizer to ensure users updates remain close [34], using a primal-dual optimization perspective [35], and more [36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41, 42, 32, 43, 44, 45].

In this work we adopt the technique used in the SCAFFOLD algorithm [42], which uses control variates to reduce the user-drift and ensure that the user updates are aligned with each other. Specifically, SCAFFOLD estimates the update direction (i.e., gradient) for the server model (c𝑐c) and the update direction for each user cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} referred to as a control variant. The difference (c−ci𝑐subscript𝑐𝑖c-c_{i}) is then an estimate of the user-drift which is used to correct the local update, as we elaborate on Section IV. This strategy successfully overcomes heterogeneity and converges in a significantly smaller number of communication rounds compared to FedAvg. However, SCAFFOLD is implemented in an ideal scenario assuming that the received local models at the server are error-free. Here, we implement the technique of control variates over noisy channels, and analyze the trade-off between the errors corresponding to heterogeneity and channel noise on the convergence rate. To handle statistical heterogeneity of users data, we extend BAAF and develop the COBAAF algorithm. First, we use control variates in the local updates of the users to address the drift induced by the statistical heterogeneity of the data. Then, similarly to BAAF, we use OTA transmission for both models and controls variates with an appropriate precoding, and implement minimum mean-square error (MMSE) estimation to mitigate the noise effect. Finally, the estimated global model and control vairates are distributed to the users for another round.

We analyze the convergence of models trained by COBAAF in heterogeneous and noisy environments to the minimal achievable loss function. We rigorously show the effect of our MMSE aggregation on the convergence of the algorithm compared to SCAFFOLD [42] that assumed noise-free and fading-free channels, and show superior performances over COTAF [31] in terms of coping with statistical heterogeneity. We further exploit an important trade-off between the channel error (determined by the MSE of the Bayesian estimation) and the heterogeneity error (determined by the gradient dissimilarity parameter). Finally, we analyze the performance of COBAAF numerically, and demonstrate its improved convergence compared to existing algorithms in simulation results.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Section II briefly reviews the FedAvg algorithm and some of its relevant extensions, and presents the system model of Bayesian OTA FL. Section III presents the BAAF algorithm along with its theoretical convergence analysis. In Section IV we present the extension to the heterogeneous setting and present the COBAAF algorithm along with its convergence analysis. Numerical results are described in Section V. Finally, Section VI provides concluding remarks. Detailed proofs of our main results are given in the appendix.

Throughout the paper, we use boldface lower-case letters for vectors, e.g., 𝒙𝒙{\boldsymbol{x}}. The ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm, stochastic expectation, and Gaussian distribution are denoted by ||⋅||||\cdot||, 𝔼​[⋅]𝔼delimited-[]⋅\mathbb{E}[\cdot], and 𝒩​(⋅,⋅)𝒩⋅⋅\mathcal{N}(\cdot,\cdot), respectively. Finally, 𝑰nsubscript𝑰𝑛{\boldsymbol{I}}_{n} is the n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n identity matrix, and ℝℝ\mathbb{R} is the set of real numbers.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

In this section we detail the system model for which BAAF is derived. In Section IV we extend BAAF to cope with the heterogeneous nature of FL, and present the COBAAF algorithm.

II-A Federated Learning Architecture

We consider a set of N𝑁N users, indexed by 𝒩≜{1,…,N}≜𝒩1…𝑁\mathcal{N}\triangleq\{1,\ldots,N\}. Each user (say user i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}) has access to a local data set 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} of Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} entities, denoted by {𝒔in}n=1Disuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑛𝑛1subscript𝐷𝑖\{{\boldsymbol{s}}_{i}^{n}\}_{n=1}^{D_{i}}, sampled in an i.i.d. fashion from 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, where sinsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑛s_{i}^{n} consists of the training input and the corresponding label. We assume that the data between users is heterogeneous, i.e., the local distributions {𝒟i}subscript𝒟𝑖\{\mathcal{D}_{i}\} are non-identical. Each user uses its data set to train a local model comprised of d𝑑d parameters, represented by the vector 𝜽∈Θ⊂ℝd𝜽Θsuperscriptℝ𝑑{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\in\Theta\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}. Training is carried out to minimize a local objective fi​(𝜽)subscript𝑓𝑖𝜽f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}), based on a loss measure l​(⋅;𝜽)𝑙⋅𝜽l(\cdot;{\boldsymbol{\theta}}). The local objective for user i𝑖i is given by:

fi​(𝜽)=1Di​∑n=1Dil​(𝒔in;𝜽).subscript𝑓𝑖𝜽1subscript𝐷𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝐷𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑛𝜽\displaystyle f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}})=\frac{1}{D_{i}}\sum\limits_{n=1}^{D_{i}}l({\boldsymbol{s}}_{i}^{n};{\boldsymbol{\theta}}). (1)

Consequently, the objective of user i𝑖i is to recover the parameters 𝜽isubscript𝜽𝑖\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i} that minimize (1):

𝜽i∗=arg⁡min𝜽⁡fi​(𝜽).superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖subscript𝜽subscript𝑓𝑖𝜽\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{*}=\arg\min_{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}). (2)

The objective of the server is to utilize the data available at the users side to train a global model with parameters 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}. The objective used for learning 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} is given by:

F​(𝜽)=1N​∑i=1Nfi​(𝜽).𝐹𝜽1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖𝜽F(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{N}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}). (3)

Consequently, the server aims to solve the following minimization problem:

𝜽∗=arg⁡min𝜽⁡F​(𝜽).superscript𝜽subscript𝜽𝐹𝜽\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}F(\boldsymbol{\theta}). (4)

II-B Federated Averaging

Federated Averaging (FedAvg) is a distributed learning algorithm aimed at recovering (4), without having the users share their local data. We first present the algorithm when executed over an error-free channel. The iterative algorithm carries out multiple training rounds, each consisting of the following three phases:

  1. 1.

    In global round r𝑟r, starting from the shared model 𝜽i,0r=𝜽r−1subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑟𝑖0superscript𝜽𝑟1{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}_{i,0}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}, each user i𝑖i trains its local model using its local data set over K𝐾K SGD local steps, namely,

    𝜽i,kr=𝜽i,k−1r−η​𝒈i​(𝜽i,k−1r),k=1,…,K,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟𝜂subscript𝒈𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟𝑘1…𝐾{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k}^{r}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}-\eta{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}),k=1,\ldots,K, (5)

    where 𝒈i​(𝜽i,k−1r)=∇fi​(𝜽i,k−1r,ξi,k−1)subscript𝒈𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟subscript𝜉𝑖𝑘1{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r})=\nabla f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r},\xi_{i,k-1}) is an unbiased stochastic gradient of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} at local step k𝑘k satisfying 𝔼ξ​[𝒈i​(𝜽)]=∇fi​(𝜽)subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]subscript𝒈𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝜽\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}})]=\nabla f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}), and η𝜂\eta is the step size.

  2. 2.

    Each user i𝑖i conveys its trained local model 𝜽i,Krsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝐾𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,K}^{r} (or alternatively, the updates in its trained model 𝜽i,Kr−𝜽i,0rsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝐾𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖0𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,K}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r}) to the central server, which averages them into a global model via 𝜽r=1N​∑i=1N𝜽i,Krsuperscript𝜽𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝐾𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,K}^{r}.

  3. 3.

    The server shares its new model with the users for the next round.

The uplink transmission in this algorithm is typically executed over an error-free channel with limited throughput, where channel noise and fading are assumed to be eliminated. In this paper, we consider transmissions in practical wireless networks, and we thus address the aggregated scheme in the present of channel noise and channel fading, as detailed in the sequel.

II-C Statistical and Communication Channel Model

As commonly assumed in OTA FL studies (see e.g., [31, 20, 26, 46]), the N𝑁N users transmit their data to the server via a MAC, since the uplink communication is typically notably more constrained as compared to its downlink counterpart in terms of throughput. The downlink channel used for server transmissions is modeled as supporting reliable communications at arbitrary rates.

We next formulate the uplink channel model. Each user conveys its local model 𝜽ir≜𝜽i,Kr≜superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝐾𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}\triangleq{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,K}^{r} to a channel input 𝒙irsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r} (which we define precisely in Section III-A). Wireless channels are inherently a shared and noisy media. Hence, each user of index i𝑖i experiences at round r𝑟r a block fading channel h~ir=hir​ej​ϕirsuperscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑟superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑟\tilde{h}_{i}^{r}=h_{i}^{r}e^{j\phi_{i}^{r}}, where hir>0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑟0h_{i}^{r}>0 and ej​ϕir∈[−π,π]superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑟𝜋𝜋e^{j\phi_{i}^{r}}\in[-\pi,\pi] are its magnitude and phase, respectively. The channel output received by the server at communication round r𝑟r when each user transmits a d×1𝑑1d\times 1 vector 𝒙irsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r}, is thus given by

𝒚~r=∑i=1Nh~ir​𝒙ir+𝒘~r,superscript~𝒚𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑟superscriptbold-~𝒘𝑟\tilde{{\boldsymbol{y}}}^{r}=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}\tilde{h}_{i}^{r}{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r}+{\boldsymbol{\tilde{w}}}^{r}, (6)

where 𝒘~r∼𝒩​(0,σw2​𝑰d)similar-tosuperscriptbold-~𝒘𝑟𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2subscript𝑰𝑑{\boldsymbol{\tilde{w}}}^{r}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{w}^{2}{\boldsymbol{I}}_{d}) is a d×1𝑑1d\times 1 vector of additive noise. The channel input is subject to an average power constraint:

𝔼​[‖𝒙ir‖2]≤P,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑟2𝑃\mathbb{E}[||{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r}||^{2}]\leq P, (7)

where P>0𝑃0P>0 represents the available transmission power.

To simplify the presentation, we start by assuming a unit fading, i.e., h~ir=1superscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑖𝑟1\tilde{h}_{i}^{r}=1 for all r,i𝑟𝑖r,i. In Section IV-E we extend the design and analysis to transmissions over fading MAC with general fading values.

We now present the statistical framework for our aggregation scheme. The motivation of our proposed algorithm is to find an optimal aggregation method of local weights from a Bayesian viewpoint. Characterizing the prior distribution of local weights is very challenging because it not only depends on the loss function but also on the underlying distribution of data samples. To overcome this difficulty, we model the distribution of the local weights as a Gaussian prior distribution with a proper moment matching technique. Specifically, we model the d𝑑d elements of 𝜽ir=[θir,1,…​θir,d]superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑟1…superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑟𝑑{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}=[\theta_{i}^{r,1},\ldots\theta_{i}^{r,d}] as i.i.d Gaussian random variables with common mean μirsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑟\mu_{i}^{r} and variance (σir)2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑟2(\sigma_{i}^{r})^{2}, which can be computed by performing offline simulations over a smaller data set, and therefore can be stored prior to the execution of the algorithm. The prior distribution can change over communication rounds according to the underlying distribution of data samples and the local loss function. We assume that 𝜽irsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r} and 𝜽nrsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}^{r} are uncorrelated for i≠n𝑖𝑛i\neq n, as assumed in [29].

III The Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated-learning (BAAF) Algorithm

III-A Algorithm Design

We now present the proposed BAAF algorithm. First, we adapt the method proposed in [31], where each user first precodes its model update 𝜽ir−𝜽i,0rsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖0𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r} into the MAC channel input 𝒙irsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r} via:

𝒙ir=αr​(𝜽ir−𝜽i,0r),superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑟superscript𝛼𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖0𝑟{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r}=\sqrt{\alpha^{r}}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r}), (8)

where αrsuperscript𝛼𝑟\sqrt{\alpha^{r}} is a precoding factor set to gradually amplify the model updates as r𝑟r progresses, while satisfying the power constraint (7). The precoder αrsuperscript𝛼𝑟\sqrt{\alpha^{r}} is given by

αr≜Pmaxi⁡𝔼​[‖𝜽ir−𝜽i,0r‖2].≜superscript𝛼𝑟𝑃subscript𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖0𝑟2\alpha^{r}\triangleq\frac{P}{\max_{i}\mathbb{E}[||{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r}||^{2}]}. (9)

The precoding parameter αrsuperscript𝛼𝑟\sqrt{\alpha^{r}} depends on the distribution of the updated model, which depends on the distribution of the data. It can thus be computed by performing offline simulations with smaller data sets and distributing the numerically computed coefficients among the users, as we do in our numerical study in Section V. Alternatively, when the loss function has bounded gradients, this term can be replaced with a coefficient that is determined by the bound on the norm of the gradients (see [31]).

In each communication round, the server thus receives the noisy sum of local model updates:

𝒚~r=∑i=1Nαr​(𝜽ir−𝜽i,0r)+𝒘~r.superscript~𝒚𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscript𝛼𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖0𝑟superscriptbold-~𝒘𝑟\tilde{{\boldsymbol{y}}}^{r}=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}\sqrt{\alpha^{r}}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r})+{\boldsymbol{\tilde{w}}}^{r}. (10)

In order to recover the aggregated global model 𝜽rsuperscript𝜽𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r} from 𝒚~rsuperscript~𝒚𝑟\tilde{{\boldsymbol{y}}}^{r}, the server sets:

𝜽~r=𝒚~rN​αr+𝜽r−1,superscript~𝜽𝑟superscript~𝒚𝑟𝑁superscript𝛼𝑟superscript𝜽𝑟1\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r}=\frac{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{y}}}^{r}}{N\sqrt{\alpha^{r}}}+{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}, (11)

which can be equivalently written as:

𝜽~r=1N​∑i=1N𝜽ir+𝒘r,superscript~𝜽𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟superscript𝒘𝑟\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}+{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r}, (12)

where 𝒘r≜𝒘~rN​αr≜superscript𝒘𝑟superscript~𝒘𝑟𝑁superscript𝛼𝑟{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r}\triangleq\frac{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{w}}}^{r}}{N\sqrt{\alpha^{r}}} is the equivalent additive noise term distributed via 𝒘r∼𝒩​(0,σw2N2​αr​𝑰d)similar-tosuperscript𝒘𝑟𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2superscript𝑁2superscript𝛼𝑟subscript𝑰𝑑{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{N^{2}\alpha^{r}}{\boldsymbol{I}}_{d}).

Finally, the server aims to estimate the average 𝜽r=1N​∑i=1N𝜽irsuperscript𝜽𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}. Our goal is thus to find a function U​(𝜽~r)𝑈superscript~𝜽𝑟U(\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r}) such that

𝜽^MMSEr=arg⁡minU⁡𝔼​[‖𝜽r−U​(𝜽~r)‖22].superscriptsubscript^𝜽MMSE𝑟subscript𝑈𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝜽𝑟𝑈superscript~𝜽𝑟22\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{\text{MMSE}}^{r}=\arg\min_{U}\mathbb{E}\left[||{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}-U(\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r})||_{2}^{2}\right]. (13)

Let 𝜽^MMSEr≜[θ^MMSEr,1,…,θ^MMSEr,d]T≜subscriptsuperscriptbold-^𝜽𝑟MMSEsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript^𝜃𝑟1MMSE…subscriptsuperscript^𝜃𝑟𝑑MMSE𝑇{\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}}^{r}_{\text{MMSE}}\triangleq[\hat{\theta}^{r,1}_{\text{MMSE}},\ldots,\hat{\theta}^{r,d}_{\text{MMSE}}]^{T}, and 𝜽~r≜[θ~r,1,…,θ~r,d]T≜superscriptbold-~𝜽𝑟superscriptsuperscript~𝜃𝑟1…superscript~𝜃𝑟𝑑𝑇{\boldsymbol{\tilde{\theta}}}^{r}\triangleq[\tilde{\theta}^{r,1},\ldots,\tilde{\theta}^{r,d}]^{T}. The MSE-optimal function for the optimization problems in (13) is obtained by the conditional expectation [47]:

θ^MMSEr,m=𝔼​[θr,m|𝜽~r]=μr+(σr)2(σr)2+σw2αr​N2​(θ~r,m−μr),superscriptsubscript^𝜃MMSE𝑟𝑚𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscript𝜃𝑟𝑚superscript~𝜽𝑟superscript𝜇𝑟superscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑟2superscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑟2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2superscript𝛼𝑟superscript𝑁2superscript~𝜃𝑟𝑚superscript𝜇𝑟\displaystyle\hat{\theta}_{\text{MMSE}}^{r,m}=\mathbb{E}\left[\theta^{r,m}|\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r}\right]=\mu^{r}+\frac{(\sigma^{r})^{2}}{(\sigma^{r})^{2}+\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{\alpha^{r}N^{2}}}(\tilde{\theta}^{r,m}-\mu^{r}), (14)

where μr≜1N​∑i=1Nμir≜superscript𝜇𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑟\mu^{r}\triangleq\frac{1}{N}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}\mu_{i}^{r} and (σr)2≜1N2​∑i=1N(σir)2≜superscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑟21superscript𝑁2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑟2(\sigma^{r})^{2}\triangleq\frac{1}{N^{2}}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}(\sigma_{i}^{r})^{2}. Eq. (14) is proved in Appendix B. We note that in order to evaluate the estimator in (14), the server requires to know μirsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑟\mu_{i}^{r}, (σir)2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑟2(\sigma_{i}^{r})^{2} and σw2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2\sigma_{w}^{2}. User i𝑖i can send these parameters using a powerful channel code (e.g., polar codes) so that the server perfectly decodes them. When 𝜽irsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r} and 𝜽nrsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}^{r} are correlated or when the elements of 𝜽irsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r} are not statistically identical, the estimation in (14) is suboptimal. Nevertheless, BAAF is still a promising algorithm due to its computational scalability in both the number of mobile devices and the model size at the cost of an MSE performance loss, and numerical experiments presented in Section V indicate that BAAF indeed mitigates effectively the channel noise.

After computing the estimated sum in (14), the server sends back 𝜽^MMSErsuperscriptsubscriptbold-^𝜽MMSE𝑟{\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}}_{\text{MMSE}}^{r} to the users, and the local model is updated by: 𝜽i,0r+1=𝜽^MMSErsubscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑟1𝑖0superscriptsubscriptbold-^𝜽MMSE𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r+1}_{i,0}={\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}}_{\text{MMSE}}^{r}. The local updated rule of user i𝑖i at round r+1𝑟1r+1 under BAAF is then given by:

𝜽i,kr+1=𝜽i,k−1r+1−ηl​𝒈i​(𝜽i,k−1r+1),k=1,…,K.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟1subscript𝜂𝑙subscript𝒈𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟1𝑘1…𝐾{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k}^{r+1}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r+1}-\eta_{l}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r+1}),k=1,\ldots,K. (15)

The final output of the algorithm is a weighted average for some positive weights (defined explicitly in Appendix C) {wr}subscript𝑤𝑟\{w_{r}\} for r∈{1,…,R+1}𝑟1…𝑅1r\in\{1,\ldots,R+1\}

𝜽¯R=1∑rwr​∑rwr​𝜽^MMSEr−1.superscriptbold-¯𝜽𝑅1subscript𝑟subscript𝑤𝑟subscript𝑟subscript𝑤𝑟superscriptsubscriptbold-^𝜽MMSE𝑟1{\boldsymbol{\bar{\theta}}}^{R}=\frac{1}{\sum_{r}w_{r}}\sum_{r}w_{r}{\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}}_{\text{MMSE}}^{r-1}. (16)

The pseudocode of BAAF is given in Algorithm 1.

III-B Theoretical Analysis

We next analyze theoretically the convergence of BAAF to the optimal model parameters 𝜽∗superscript𝜽{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}, i.e., the vector 𝜽𝜽{\boldsymbol{\theta}} which minimizes the global loss function. Our analysis is carried out under standard strong-convexity, smoothness, and bounded gradients assumptions used in SGD and FL studies (see e.g., [32, 33, 31, 20]):
AS1: Each function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is β𝛽\beta-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex.
AS2: The unbiased stochastic gradients gi​(𝜽)subscript𝑔𝑖𝜽g_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}) satisfy 𝔼ξ​[‖gi​(𝜽)−∇fi​(𝜽)‖2]≤σ2subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝜽2superscript𝜎2\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[||g_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}})-\nabla f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}})||^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2} and 𝔼ξ​[‖gi​(𝜽)‖2]≤M2subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑖𝜽2superscript𝑀2\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[||g_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}})||^{2}]\leq M^{2} for some fixed σ2>0superscript𝜎20\sigma^{2}>0 and M2>0superscript𝑀20M^{2}>0, for each 𝜽∈Θ𝜽Θ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\in\Theta and i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}.
AS3: There exist constants G≥0𝐺0G\geq 0 and B≥1𝐵1B\geq 1 such that:

1N​∑i=1N‖∇fi​(𝜽)‖2≤G2+B2​‖∇f​(𝜽)‖2,∀𝜽∈Θ.formulae-sequence1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝜽2superscript𝐺2superscript𝐵2superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝜽2for-all𝜽Θ\frac{1}{N}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}||\nabla f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}})||^{2}\leq G^{2}+B^{2}||\nabla f({\boldsymbol{\theta}})||^{2},\;\forall{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\in\Theta.

We next present the resulted MMSE estimation error.

Proposition 1

The minimum MSE, MSE​(θ^MMSEr,m)≜𝔼​[(θr,m−θ^MMSEr,m)2]≜MSEsubscriptsuperscript^𝜃𝑟𝑚MMSE𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑟𝑚subscriptsuperscript^𝜃𝑟𝑚MMSE2\text{MSE}(\hat{\theta}^{r,m}_{\text{MMSE}})\triangleq\mathbb{E}\left[(\theta^{r,m}-\hat{\theta}^{r,m}_{\text{MMSE}})^{2}\right], is given by:

MSE​(θ^MMSEr,m)=1N2​αr⋅σw21+σw2αr​N2​(σr)2=1N2​αr⋅σθr,MSEsubscriptsuperscript^𝜃𝑟𝑚MMSE⋅1superscript𝑁2superscript𝛼𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤21superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2superscript𝛼𝑟superscript𝑁2superscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑟2⋅1superscript𝑁2superscript𝛼𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃𝑟\text{MSE}(\hat{\theta}^{r,m}_{\text{MMSE}})=\frac{1}{N^{2}\alpha^{r}}\cdot\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{1+\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{\alpha^{r}N^{2}(\sigma^{r})^{2}}}=\frac{1}{N^{2}\alpha^{r}}\cdot\sigma_{\theta}^{r}, (17)

where σθr≜σw21+σw2αr​N2​(σr)2≜superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤21superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2superscript𝛼𝑟superscript𝑁2superscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑟2\sigma_{\theta}^{r}\triangleq\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{1+\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{\alpha^{r}N^{2}(\sigma^{r})^{2}}}.

We next establish a finite-sample bound on the error, given by the expected loss in the objective value at global round R𝑅R with respect to F​(𝜽∗)𝐹superscript𝜽F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}).

Theorem 1

Suppose that each of the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} satisfies assumptions AS1,AS2,AS3. Then, there exist weights {wr}subscript𝑤𝑟\{w_{r}\} and local step sizes ηl≤18​β​K​(1+B2)subscript𝜂𝑙18𝛽𝐾1superscript𝐵2\eta_{l}\leq\frac{1}{8\beta K(1+B^{2})} such that the output (16) of the BAAF algorithm for any R≥8​β​(1+B2)μ𝑅8𝛽1superscript𝐵2𝜇R\geq\frac{8\beta(1+B^{2})}{\mu} satisfies:

𝔼​[F​(𝜽¯R)]−F​(𝜽∗)𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptbold-¯𝜽𝑅𝐹superscript𝜽\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F({\boldsymbol{\bar{\theta}}}^{R})]-F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*})
≤(3​σ2​(1+N)μ​R​K​N+3​d​M2​σθμ​R​N2​P)⋅log⁡(max⁡{μ2​R​d0c1})absent⋅3superscript𝜎21𝑁𝜇𝑅𝐾𝑁3𝑑superscript𝑀2subscript𝜎𝜃𝜇𝑅superscript𝑁2𝑃superscript𝜇2𝑅subscript𝑑0subscript𝑐1\displaystyle\leq\left(\frac{3\sigma^{2}(1+N)}{\mu RKN}+\frac{3dM^{2}\sigma_{\theta}}{\mu RN^{2}P}\right)\cdot\log(\max\{\mu^{2}R\frac{d_{0}}{c_{1}}\})
+3​β​G2μ2​R2log2(max{μ2Rd0c2}\displaystyle+\frac{3\beta G^{2}}{\mu^{2}R^{2}}\log^{2}(\max\{\mu^{2}R\frac{d_{0}}{c_{2}}\}
+\displaystyle+ 3​μ​‖𝜽^𝟎−𝜽∗‖2​exp⁡(−μ​R16​β​(1+B2)),3𝜇superscriptnormsuperscriptbold-^𝜽0superscript𝜽2𝜇𝑅16𝛽1superscript𝐵2\displaystyle 3\mu||{\boldsymbol{\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{0}-\theta^{*}}}||^{2}\exp\left(-\frac{\mu R}{16\beta(1+B^{2})}\right), (18)

where σθ≜maxr∈[R],m∈[d]⁡σθr≜subscript𝜎𝜃subscriptformulae-sequence𝑟delimited-[]𝑅𝑚delimited-[]𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃𝑟\sigma_{\theta}\triangleq\displaystyle\max_{r\in[R],m\in[d]}\sigma_{\theta}^{r}, c1=σ2​(1+N)K​N+d​M2​σθN2​Psubscript𝑐1superscript𝜎21𝑁𝐾𝑁𝑑superscript𝑀2subscript𝜎𝜃superscript𝑁2𝑃c_{1}=\frac{\sigma^{2}(1+N)}{KN}+\frac{dM^{2}\sigma_{\theta}}{N^{2}P}, c2=β​G2subscript𝑐2𝛽superscript𝐺2c_{2}=\beta G^{2}, d0=‖𝜽^𝟎−𝜽∗‖2subscript𝑑0superscriptnormsuperscriptbold-^𝜽0superscript𝜽2d_{0}=||{\boldsymbol{\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{0}-\theta^{*}}}||^{2}.
The proof is given in Appendix C. Theorem 1 gives a clean expression of how the four terms– the initial distance due to the error in the initial estimate, the variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} due to the stochastic gradients, the error σθsubscript𝜎𝜃\sigma_{\theta} due to the noisy channel and the gradient dissimilarity parameter G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} – characterize the error bound.

Comparing Theorem 1 to the corresponding convergence rate of FedAvg derived in [42, Theorem 1], which considered noise-free channels, we observe that BAAF achieves the same convergence rate, with an additional term which depends on the MSE induced by the channel noise. Larger MSEs make the convergence speed slower. By using the MMSE aggregation function that provides the minimum MSE, we can speed up the convergence rate. Additionally, by increasing N𝑁N this distortion term diminishes. When the MSE equals to 00 (i.e., when σθ=0subscript𝜎𝜃0\sigma_{\theta}=0), Theorem 1 coincides with [42, Theorem 1]. Additionally, comparing Theorem 1 to the corresponding result in [31], which does not apply MMSE estimation to the channel output, we observe that the error term that depends on the channel noise in BAAF, σθ/Psubscript𝜎𝜃𝑃\sigma_{\theta}/P, is smaller than the corresponding term σw2/Psuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2𝑃\sigma_{w}^{2}/P obtained in [31], which improves the convergence result.

Finally, the gradient dissimilarity parameter G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} term in Th. 1 determines the decrease in the convergence rate as a result of the user-drift, which is a result of the non i.i.d nature of the users’ data (i.e., the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are distinct). In more details, let 𝜽∗superscript𝜽{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*} be the global optimum of F​(𝜽)𝐹𝜽F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}), and 𝜽i∗superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{*} be the optimum of each user’s loss function fi​(𝜽)subscript𝑓𝑖𝜽f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}). In the case of heterogeneous data, it is quite likely that each of these 𝜽i∗superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{*} is far away from the other, and from the global optimum 𝜽∗superscript𝜽{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}. The difference between 1N​∑i=1N𝜽i∗1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{*} (which is the server update) and the true optimum 𝜽∗superscript𝜽{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*} results in a user-drift. In the next section, we use the technique of control variates [42, 41] to mitigate this effect.

IV The Controlled Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated learning (COBBAF) Algorithm

We now extend the BAAF algorithm by implementing a variance reduction technique in the form of control variates in the local updates, thus reducing the negative effect of users-drift.

IV-A Federated Averaging with Control Variates

The local updates of FedAvg (as in BAAF) leads to a drift in the update of each user resulting in slow and unstable convergence. We thus develop COBAAF using the technique of control variates for the local updates. As proposed in [42, 41], along with the server model 𝜽𝜽{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, in each round r𝑟r we maintain a state for each user (user control variate 𝒄ir≜𝒈i​(𝜽r−1)≜superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝜽𝑟1{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}\triangleq{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1})) and for the server (server control variate 𝒄r≜1N​∑i=1N𝒄ir≜superscript𝒄𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r}\triangleq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}). We first present the algorithm when executed over an error-free channel. The iterative algorithm carries out multiple training rounds, each consisting of the following three phases:

  1. 1.

    In global round r𝑟r, starting from the shared model 𝜽i,0r=𝜽r−1subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑟𝑖0superscript𝜽𝑟1{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}_{i,0}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}, each user i𝑖i trains its local model using its local data set and the control variates over K𝐾K SGD local steps, namely,

    𝜽i,kr=𝜽i,k−1r−ηl​(𝒈i​(𝜽i,k−1r)−𝒄ir−1+𝒄r−1),superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟subscript𝜂𝑙subscript𝒈𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟1superscript𝒄𝑟1\begin{array}[]{c}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k}^{r}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}-\eta_{l}({\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r})-{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r-1}+{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r-1}),\end{array} (19)
  2. 2.

    Each user i𝑖i then updates the control variate: 𝒄ir=𝒈i​(𝜽r−1)superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝜽𝑟1{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}={\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}).

  3. 3.

    Each user i𝑖i conveys its trained local model 𝜽i,Krsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝐾𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,K}^{r} and the updated control variate 𝒄irsuperscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r} to the central server, which averages them into a global model via 𝜽r=1N​∑i=1N𝜽i,Krsuperscript𝜽𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝐾𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,K}^{r}, and a global control variate 𝒄r=1N​∑i=1N𝒄irsuperscript𝒄𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}, and sends the new model and control to the users for another round.

We next briefly explain the rationale behind the design of the algorithm. If communication is not a concern, then the ideal local update of user i𝑖i at global round r𝑟r would be 𝜽i,kr=𝜽i,k−1r−1N​∑j=1N𝒈j​(𝜽i,k−1r)superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝒈𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k}^{r}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{j}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}). Such an update essentially computes an unbiased gradient of F​(𝜽)𝐹𝜽F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}) and hence becomes equivalent to running FedAvg in the i.i.d. case (which is known to have strong performance). Unfortunately, such an update requires communicating with all users for every update step. Instead, the procedure above uses control variates such that 𝒄i=𝒈i​(𝜽r−1)subscript𝒄𝑖subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝜽𝑟1{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}={\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}) and 𝒄=1N​∑j=1N𝒄j𝒄1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝒄𝑗{\boldsymbol{c}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{j} for the whole round r𝑟r. Since the gradient of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is Lipschitz, it is expected that 𝒈i​(𝜽r−1)≈𝒈i​(𝜽i,k−1r)subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝜽𝑟1subscript𝒈𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1})\approx{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}) as long as the local updates are not too large and 𝜽r−1≈𝜽i,k−1rsuperscript𝜽𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}\approx{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}. Then, the ideal update is estimated by: (𝒈i​(𝜽i,k−1r)−𝒈i​(𝜽r−1)+1N​∑j=1N𝒈j​(𝜽r−1))≈1N​∑j=1N𝒈j​(𝜽i,k−1r)subscript𝒈𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝜽𝑟11𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝒈𝑗superscript𝜽𝑟11𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝒈𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑘1𝑟({\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r})-{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1})+\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{j}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}))\approx\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{j}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}). Thus, the local updates do not drift and remain synchronized and converge under heterogeneous users.

We next address the aggregated scheme of COBAAF in the present of channel noise.

IV-B Communication and Statistical Model

In the iterative algorithm presented above the users are required to send additional information to the server, the controls 𝒄i≜𝒈i​(𝜽r−1)≜subscript𝒄𝑖subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝜽𝑟1{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}\triangleq{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}). However, we again observe that the server only needs to receive the average value 1N​∑i=1N𝒄i1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝒄𝑖\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}, where the individual control value {𝒄i}subscript𝒄𝑖\{{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}\} is not required. Thus, each user precodes its control 𝒈i​(𝜽r−1)subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝜽𝑟1{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}) into the MAC channel input via βr​𝒈i​(𝜽r−1)superscript𝛽𝑟subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝜽𝑟1\sqrt{\beta^{r}}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}), where

We now present the steps of COBAAF. In each communication round, the server observes the noisy sum of local models 𝜽~rsuperscript~𝜽𝑟\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r} and control variates 𝒄~rsuperscript~𝒄𝑟\tilde{{\boldsymbol{c}}}^{r}, and first needs to estimate the average values 𝜽r=1N​∑i=1N𝜽irsuperscript𝜽𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r} and 𝒄r=1N​∑i=1N𝒄irsuperscript𝒄𝑟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}. IV-D Theoretical Analysis

We next establish a finite-sample bound on the error of the COBAAF algorithm, given by the expected loss in the objective value at global round R𝑅R with respect to F​(𝜽∗)𝐹superscript𝜽F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}).

Theorem 2

Suppose that each of the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} satisfies assumptions AS1,AS2. Then, there exist weights {wr}subscript𝑤𝑟\{w_{r}\} and local step sizes ηl≤18​β​Ksubscript𝜂𝑙18𝛽𝐾\eta_{l}\leq\frac{1}{8\beta K} such that the output (16) of the COBAAF algorithm for any R≥8​βμ𝑅8𝛽𝜇R\geq\frac{8\beta}{\mu} satisfies:

𝔼​[F​(𝜽¯R)]−F​(𝜽∗)𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptbold-¯𝜽𝑅𝐹superscript𝜽\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F({\boldsymbol{\bar{\theta}}}^{R})]-F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*})
≤\displaystyle\leq (2​σ2​(1+N)μ​R​K​N+2​d​M2​σθμ​R​K​N2​P+2​d​M2​σc​(1+N​K)μ​R​K​N2​P)2superscript𝜎21𝑁𝜇𝑅𝐾𝑁2𝑑superscript𝑀2subscript𝜎𝜃𝜇𝑅𝐾superscript𝑁2𝑃2𝑑superscript𝑀2subscript𝜎𝑐1𝑁𝐾𝜇𝑅𝐾superscript𝑁2𝑃\displaystyle\left(\frac{2\sigma^{2}(1+N)}{\mu RKN}+\frac{2dM^{2}\sigma_{\theta}}{\mu RKN^{2}P}+\frac{2dM^{2}\sigma_{c}(1+NK)}{\mu RKN^{2}P}\right)
⋅log⁡(max⁡{1,μ2​R​d0/c3})⋅absent1superscript𝜇2𝑅subscript𝑑0subscript𝑐3\displaystyle\cdot\log(\max\{1,\mu^{2}Rd_{0}/c_{3}\})
+\displaystyle+ 2​μ​‖𝜽^𝟎−𝜽∗‖2​exp⁡(−μ​R16​β),2𝜇superscriptnormsuperscriptbold-^𝜽0superscript𝜽2𝜇𝑅16𝛽\displaystyle 2\mu||{\boldsymbol{\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{0}-\theta^{*}}}||^{2}\exp\left(-\frac{\mu R}{16\beta}\right), (28)

where σcr=maxr∈[R],m∈[d]⁡σcrsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑐𝑟subscriptformulae-sequence𝑟delimited-[]𝑅𝑚delimited-[]𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑐𝑟\sigma_{c}^{r}=\max_{r\in[R],m\in[d]}\sigma_{c}^{r}, σcr≜σw21+σw2βr​∑i=1N(vir)2≜superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑐𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤21superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2superscript𝛽𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑟2\sigma_{c}^{r}\triangleq\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{1+\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{\beta^{r}\sum_{i=1}^{N}(v_{i}^{r})^{2}}}, c3=σ2​(1+N)K​N+d​M2​σθK​N2​P+d​M2​σc​(1+N​K)K​N2​Psubscript𝑐3superscript𝜎21𝑁𝐾𝑁𝑑superscript𝑀2subscript𝜎𝜃𝐾superscript𝑁2𝑃𝑑superscript𝑀2subscript𝜎𝑐1𝑁𝐾𝐾superscript𝑁2𝑃c_{3}=\frac{\sigma^{2}(1+N)}{KN}+\frac{dM^{2}\sigma_{\theta}}{KN^{2}P}+\frac{dM^{2}\sigma_{c}(1+NK)}{KN^{2}P}.

The proof is given in Appendix D.

Similarly to Theorem 1, Theorem 2 gives a clean expression of how the four terms– the initial distance due to the error in the initial estimate, the variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} due to the stochastic gradients, and the errors σθsubscript𝜎𝜃\sigma_{\theta}, σcsubscript𝜎𝑐\sigma_{c} due to the noisy channel – characterize the error bound. Comparing Theorem 2 to the corresponding result in [42], which considered noise-free channels, we observe that COBAAF achieves the same convergence rate, with an additional terms which depend on the MSE induced by the channel noise and fading. Larger MSEs make the convergence speed slower. By using the MMSE aggregation function that provides the minimum MSE, we can speed up the convergence rate. Additionally, by increasing N𝑁N this distortion term diminishes. When the MSE equals 00, Theorem 2 coincides with [42, Theorem 3]. Additionally, comparing Theorem 2 to the corresponding result in Theorem 1 and in [31], which considered the same setup but without addressing the statistical heterogeneity, we observe that Theorem 1 and Theorem 111 in [31] have an additional component which depends on G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} and Γ≜F∗−1N​∑n=1Nfn∗≜Γsuperscript𝐹1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛\Gamma\triangleq F^{*}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}f_{n}^{*}, respectively, that encapsulates the degree of heterogeneity. The use of control variates in COBAAF mitigates the negative effect of this term on the convergence.

Theorem 2 implies an important trade-off between communication and heterogeneity: To reduce heterogeneity, the users are required to send the additional parameters 𝒄isubscript𝒄𝑖{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}, which results in the error term σcsubscript𝜎𝑐\sigma_{c}. However, the use of the control variates mitigates the negative effect of the dissimilarity term G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} on the convergence. Finally, note that due to the OTA transmission of the COBAAF algorithm, the bandwidth requirement is independent of the number of users N𝑁N, allowing the simultaneous participation of a large number of users without limiting the throughput of each user. Practically, this transmission scheme requires coherent transmissions between users [5].

IV-E Extension to Fading Channels

In the previous subsections we focused on FL over noisy MACs, where h~ir=1superscriptsubscript~ℎ𝑖𝑟1\tilde{h}_{i}^{r}=1 for all r,i𝑟𝑖r,i. Here, we extend COBAAF to handle transmissions over fading MAC with general fading values, while preserving its proven convergence (the extension of BAAF to fading MACs can be done similarly). In fading MACs, the signal transmitted by each user undergoes a fading coefficient denoted by hir​ej​ϕirsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑟superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑟h_{i}^{r}e^{j\phi_{i}^{r}} as defined in (6) for the local model updates, and ρir​ej​φirsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑟superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜑𝑖𝑟\rho_{i}^{r}e^{j\varphi_{i}^{r}} for the control variates. In the extension here, we assume that the participating entities have channel state information (CSI), i.e., knowledge of the fading coefficients, as commonly assumed in wireless communications and particularly OTA FL (see e.g., [48, 49, 31] and subsequent studies). Such knowledge can be obtained by letting the users sense their channels, estimating the channel from pilot signals, or having the access point/server periodically estimate these coefficients and convey them to the users.

Following the scheme proposed in [31], each user utilizes its CSI to cancel the fading effect by amplifying the signal by its inverse channel coefficient. However, weak channels might cause an arbitrarily high amplification, possibly violating the transmission power constraint (7). Therefore, thresholds hmin,ρminsubscriptℎsubscript𝜌h_{\min},\rho_{\min} are set, and users observing fading coefficients of a lesser magnitude than hminsubscriptℎh_{\min} (for the model updates) or ρminsubscript𝜌\rho_{\min} (for the control variates) do not transmit in that communication round. As channels typically attenuate their signals, it holds that hmin<1,ρmin<1formulae-sequencesubscriptℎ1subscript𝜌1h_{\min}<1,\rho_{\min}<1. Under this extension of COBAAF, (8) becomes

𝒙ir={αr​hminhir​e−j​ϕir​(𝜽ir−𝜽i,0r),if​hir>hmin,0,if​hir≤hmin.superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑟casessuperscript𝛼𝑟subscriptℎsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑟superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖0𝑟ifsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑟subscriptℎ0ifsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑟subscriptℎ\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r}\!=\!\begin{cases}\frac{\sqrt{\alpha^{r}}h_{\min}}{h_{i}^{r}}e^{-j\phi_{i}^{r}}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r}),&\text{if}\;h_{i}^{r}>h_{\min},\\ 0,&\text{if}\;h_{i}^{r}\leq h_{\min}.\end{cases} (29)

Note that the energy constraint (7) is preserved. The control variates cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} are transmitted in a similar way.

To formulate the server aggregation, we let 𝒮r⊂𝒩superscript𝒮𝑟𝒩\mathcal{S}^{r}\subset\mathcal{N} be the set of user indices whose corresponding channel at round r𝑟r satisfies hir>hminsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑟subscriptℎh_{i}^{r}>h_{\min}, ρir>ρminsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑟subscript𝜌\rho_{i}^{r}>\rho_{\min}. As the server has CSI, it knows 𝒮rsuperscript𝒮𝑟\mathcal{S}^{r}, and can thus recover the aggregated model 𝜽rsuperscript𝜽𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r} and control 𝒄rsuperscript𝒄𝑟{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r} in a similar manner as in (22), via

𝜽~r=𝒚~r|𝒮r|​αr​hmin+𝜽r−1𝒄~r=𝒛~r|𝒮r|​βr​ρmin,formulae-sequencesuperscript~𝜽𝑟superscript~𝒚𝑟superscript𝒮𝑟superscript𝛼𝑟subscriptℎsuperscript𝜽𝑟1superscript~𝒄𝑟superscript~𝒛𝑟superscript𝒮𝑟superscript𝛽𝑟subscript𝜌\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r}=\frac{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{y}}}^{r}}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|\sqrt{\alpha^{r}}h_{\min}}+{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}\;\quad\quad\tilde{{\boldsymbol{c}}}^{r}=\frac{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{z}}}^{r}}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|\sqrt{\beta^{r}}\rho_{\min}}, (30)

which can be equivalently written as:

𝜽~r=1|𝒮r|​∑i∈𝒮r𝜽ir+N|𝒮r|​hmin​𝒘r,superscript~𝜽𝑟1superscript𝒮𝑟subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟𝑁superscript𝒮𝑟subscriptℎsuperscript𝒘𝑟\displaystyle\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}+\frac{N}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|h_{\min}}{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r},
𝒄~r=1|𝒮r|​∑i∈𝒮r𝒄ir+N|𝒮r|​ρmin​𝒏r.superscript~𝒄𝑟1superscript𝒮𝑟subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑟superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟𝑁superscript𝒮𝑟subscript𝜌superscript𝒏𝑟\displaystyle\tilde{{\boldsymbol{c}}}^{r}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}+\frac{N}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|\rho_{\min}}{\boldsymbol{n}}^{r}. (31)

As in Section IV-C, given 𝜽~r,𝒄~rsuperscript~𝜽𝑟superscript~𝒄𝑟\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r},\tilde{{\boldsymbol{c}}}^{r}, the server estimates the partial sums 1|𝒮r|​∑i∈𝒮r𝜽ir1superscript𝒮𝑟subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}, 1|𝒮r|​∑i∈𝒮r𝒄ir1superscript𝒮𝑟subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑟superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}, using the MMSE estimator, and sends the estimators 𝜽^r,𝒄^rsuperscript^𝜽𝑟superscript^𝒄𝑟\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r},\hat{{\boldsymbol{c}}}^{r} to the users for the next round.

Comparing (IV-E) to the corresponding equivalent formulation in (23), we note that the proposed extension of COBAAF results in two main differences from the fading-free scenario: First, the presence of fading is translated into an increase in the noise power, encapsulated in the constants N|𝒮r|​hmin>1𝑁superscript𝒮𝑟subscriptℎ1\frac{N}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|h_{\min}}>1, N|𝒮r|​ρmin>1𝑁superscript𝒮𝑟subscript𝜌1\frac{N}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|\rho_{\min}}>1. Second, fewer models are aggregated in each round as 𝒮r≤Nsuperscript𝒮𝑟𝑁\mathcal{S}^{r}\leq N. The set of participating users 𝒮rsuperscript𝒮𝑟\mathcal{S}^{r} depends on the distribution of the fading coefficients. Thus, in order to analytically characterize how the convergence is affected by fading compared to the scenario analyzed in Subsection IV-D, we introduce the following assumption:
AS4: At each communication round, the participating users set 𝒮rsuperscript𝒮𝑟\mathcal{S}^{r} contains S≤N𝑆𝑁S\leq N users and is uniformly distributed over all the subsets of 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} of cardinality S𝑆S. Note that Assumption AS4 can be imposed by a simple distributed mechanism using an opportunistic carrier sensing as described in [31].

We point out that the partial aggregation scheme induces some ’lag’ in our updates of the control variates 𝒄isubscript𝒄𝑖{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i} since only a small subset of them are updated at each round. That is, the global control 𝒄r=1S​∑i∈𝒮r𝒄irsuperscript𝒄𝑟1𝑆subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑟superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r}=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r} also drifts from the ”desired” average ∑i∈𝒩𝒄irsubscript𝑖𝒩superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖𝑟\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}. We address this point in the proof of Theorem 3.

Next, we characterize the convergence of the instantaneous global model, as stated in the following theorem:

Suppose that each of the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} satisfies assumptions AS1, AS2, AS4. The proof is given in Appendix E.

Comparing Theorem 3 to the corresponding convergence bound with fading-free channels in Theorem 3 reveals that the extension of COBAAF allows the trained model to maintain its asymptotic convergence rate of O​(1R)𝑂1𝑅O(\frac{1}{R}) in the presence of fading channel conditions as well. However, the aforementioned differences in the equivalent global model due to fading are translated here into additive terms increasing the bound on the distance between the expected instantaneous objective 𝔼​[F​(𝜽¯R)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptbold-¯𝜽𝑅\mathbb{E}[F({\boldsymbol{\bar{\theta}}}^{R})] and its desired optimal value. In particular, the increased equivalent noise results in the terms σ~c,σ~θsubscript~𝜎𝑐subscript~𝜎𝜃\tilde{\sigma}_{c},\tilde{\sigma}_{\theta} being larger than the corresponding errors σc,σθsubscript𝜎𝑐subscript𝜎𝜃\sigma_{c},\sigma_{\theta} in (2) due to the increased equivalent noise-to-signal ratio which stems from the scaling by hminsubscriptℎh_{\min} and ρminsubscript𝜌\rho_{\min} at the precoder and the corresponding aggregation at the server side. Moreover, due to the partial participation of users in the global rounds, we also need to keep track how far our control variate is from its value at the optimum as discussed above. This is encapsulated in the term D~2superscript~𝐷2\tilde{D}^{2}, which is different (and larger) than the corresponding D2superscript𝐷2D^{2} term in (2). In particular, note that the D~2superscript~𝐷2\tilde{D}^{2} defined above involves an additional term 12​S​β2∑i=1N||ci0−∇fi(θ∗)||2)\frac{1}{2S\beta^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}||c_{i}^{0}-\nabla f_{i}(\theta^{*})||^{2}) due to using a variance reduction method [50]. Practically, we will use a warm-start strategy to set 𝒄i0superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖0{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{0} and in the first N/S𝑁𝑆N/S rounds, we compute 𝒄i0=𝒈i​(𝜽0)superscriptsubscript𝒄𝑖0subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝜽0{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{0}={\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{0}) over a batch size of size K𝐾K. Then, using smoothness of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, we can bound this additional term as

≤N​D2S+N​σ2K​S​β2.absent𝑁superscript𝐷2𝑆𝑁superscript𝜎2𝐾𝑆superscript𝛽2\displaystyle\leq\frac{ND^{2}}{S}+\frac{N\sigma^{2}}{KS\beta^{2}}.

V Numerical Analysis

We now provide simulation results to demonstrate the efficiency of BAAF and COBAAF, in both regression and classification tasks. We evaluate BAAF and COBAAF on real data sets. In order to better characterize statistical heterogeneity and study its effect on convergence, we also evaluate them on a set of synthetic data, which allows for more precise manipulation of statistical heterogeneity.

V-A Linear Regression on Synthetic Data

We consider a linear regression model with a convex local loss function, i.e., fi​(𝜽)=‖𝑨iT​𝜽−𝑩i‖22subscript𝑓𝑖𝜽superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑨𝑖𝑇𝜽subscript𝑩𝑖22f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}})=||{\boldsymbol{A}}_{i}^{T}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}-{\boldsymbol{B}}_{i}||_{2}^{2}, where 𝑨isubscript𝑨𝑖{\boldsymbol{A}}_{i} is the training input and 𝑩isubscript𝑩𝑖{\boldsymbol{B}}_{i} is the corresponding level, with [Di,d]=[100,10]subscript𝐷𝑖𝑑10010[D_{i},d]=[100,10]. In Fig. 1, we present the performance evaluation when the number of users is N=20𝑁20N=20, the number of local steps is K=10𝐾10K=10 and the local step size is 10−2superscript10210^{-2}. To embrace the data heterogeneity, for each user i𝑖i we model 𝑨i∼𝒩​(ai,𝑰),ai∼𝒩​(1,α),𝜽i∼𝒩​(bi,I),bi∼𝒩​(−4,β)formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝑨𝑖𝒩subscript𝑎𝑖𝑰formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝑎𝑖𝒩1𝛼formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝜽𝑖𝒩subscript𝑏𝑖Isimilar-tosubscript𝑏𝑖𝒩4𝛽{\boldsymbol{A}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(a_{i},{\boldsymbol{I}}),a_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(1,\alpha),{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(b_{i},\emph{I}),b_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(-4,\beta), where I is the identity matrix. Therefore, α𝛼\alpha controls how much the local data at each user differs from that of other users, and β𝛽\beta controls how much local models differ from each other. We simulate MACs with signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs) of 10dB and without fading. The precoding coefficients αr,βrsuperscript𝛼𝑟superscript𝛽𝑟\alpha^{r},\beta^{r} are computed via (9),(20), respectively, using numerical averaging, i.e., we carried out offline simulations of local SGD without noise and with 20%percent2020\% of the data samples, and computed the averaged norm of the resulting model updates. We numerically evaluate the gap from the achieved expected objective and the loss-minimizing one, i.e., 𝔼​[F​(𝜽^r)]−F​(𝜽∗)𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript^𝜽𝑟𝐹superscript𝜽\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r})]-F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}). Using this performance measure, we compare BAAF and COBAAF to the following FL methods: (i) Non-precoded OTA FL (denoted in Fig. 1 as ”Noisy FedAvg”), where every user transmits its model updates over the MAC without time varying precoding (9) and with a constant amplification as in [31], i.e., 𝒙ir=P​(𝜽ir−𝜽i,0r)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑟𝑃superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖0𝑟{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r}=P({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r}); (ii) COTAF [31], in which a time varying precoding is implemented similarly as in (9), but without the use of control variates and without Bayesian aggregation at the server side; and (iii) SCAFFOLD [42] carried out over ideal orthogonal noiseless channels. The stochastic expectation is evaluated by averaging over 100100100 Monte Carlo trials, where in each trial the initial 𝜽0subscript𝜽0{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{0} is randomized from zero-mean Gaussian distribution with covariance 𝑰dsubscript𝑰𝑑{\boldsymbol{I}}_{d}.

It can be seen in Fig. 1 that BAAF (purple curve) outperforms both FedAvg carried over noisy channels (blue curve), and COTAF (red curve), indicating the gain that we achieve by using the proposed precoding scheme and Bayesian aggregation method at the server side. Note that COTAF uses precoding but does not implement Bayesian aggregation, thus the gap between BAAF and COTAF indicates the performance gain as a result of the Bayesian aggregation scheme. We also observe that COBAAF outperforms BAAF and COTAF. This implies that COBAAF indeed reduces the variance induced by heterogeneity using the control variates compared to BAAF and COTAF that do not use this technique. Note that BAAF uses precoding and implements Bayesian aggregation but does not use control variates in the local updates, thus the gap between COBAAF and BAAF indicates the performance gain as a result of the control variates. Finally, we also observe that COBAAF (green curve) achieves performances within a minor gap from that of SCAFFOLD [42] carried out over ideal orthogonal noiseless channels (pink curve). That indicates that COBAAF is able to mitigate the noise effect. It is emphasized that when using orthogonal transmissions, as implicitly assumed when using the conventional SCAFFOLD scheme, increasing the number of users implies that the channel resources must be shared among a larger number of users, hence the throughput of each user decreases. However, in OTA FL the throughput is independent of the number of users. The results presented in Fig. 1 demonstrate the benefits of COBAAF, as an OTA FL scheme which accounts for both the convergence properties of FL algorithms as well as the unique characteristics of wireless communication channels.

Next, we repeat the simulation study of Fig. 1 while increasing the number of users to be N=200𝑁200N=200 in Fig. 2. The results demonstrate the dependence of COBAAF on the number of users N𝑁N. Since the MSE resulting from the Bayesian aggregation decreases when N𝑁N increases, increasing the number of users N𝑁N improves the performance of COBAAF. In particular, COBAAF almost reaches the performance of noise-free SCAFFOLD.

Finally, we repeat the simulation study of Fig. 1 while increasing the number of local steps to be K=20𝐾20K=20 in Fig. 3 Comparing Fig. 3 to Fig. 1 reveals that increasing the SGD steps K𝐾K can improve the performance of COBAAF as the channel noise is induced less frequently. We also observe that the gap between COBAAF to COTAF increases compared to Fig. 1, since performing more local steps in heterogeneous systems increases the users drift in the COTAF algorithm. The control variates c,ci𝑐subscript𝑐𝑖c,c_{i} in COBAAF allows to utilize the local steps to improve the performance.

V-B Classification on MNIST Data set

Next, we consider an image classification problem, based on the MNIST data set [51], which contains train and test images from ten different digits. Our real data set experiments run logistic regression (convex) model as in [42]. We study two ways of partitioning the MNIST data over users: balanced partitioning, where the data is shuffled, and then partitioned into 10 users each receiving 600 examples, and imbalanced partitioning, where approximately 20%percent2020\% of the training data of each user is associated with a single label, which differs among the different users. Consequently, each user holds more images from a unique class, resulting in heterogeneity between the users. The model accuracy versus the transmission round achieved for the considered FL schemes is depicted in Figs. 4 and 5 for the homogeneous case and the heterogeneous case, respectively. We evaluate the performances when the number of local steps is K=5𝐾5K=5, the number of users is N=10𝑁10N=10, the SNR is 101010dB without fading, and the learning rate is 10−2superscript10210^{-2}.

Observing Fig. 4, we note that in the homogeneous setting, BAAF (green curve) outperforms both FedAvg over noisy channels (red curve), and COTAF (cyan curve), indicating the gain that we achieve also in this classification task by using the proposed precoding scheme and Bayesian aggregation method at the server side. The gap between BAAF and COTAF indicates the performance gain as a result of the Bayesian aggregation scheme. Finally, we also observe that BAAF achieves performances within a minor gap from that of FedAvg (purple curve) carried over ideal orthogonal noiseless channels (which has great performances in the homogeneous case).

Finally, in Fig. 5 we compared the performances of the algorithms in the MNIST classification task in the heterogeneous setting over noisy channels. We observe that the proposed CoBAAF algorithm outperforms COTAF, with a larger gap than in the homogeneous case. This is due to the ability of CoBAAF to handle heterogeneous data sets. By employing precoding and Bayesian aggregation, COBBAF is able to almost achieve the performance of SCAFFOLD over a noiseless channel.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we developed two OTA FL algorithms for combating noise and heterogeneity. Our proposed BAAF algorithm is based on a rigorous Bayesian approach for signal aggregation to mitigate the noise and fading effects induced by the channel. To handle heterogeneity, we developed COBAAF, which extends BAAF and uses a control variates technique. We rigorously prove that the BAAF and COBAAF converge to the loss minimizing model with the same asymptotic convergence rate of FedAvg [4] and SCAFFOLD [42] (respectively) without communication constraints. The strong performances of COBAAF are achieved by combining the transmission and Bayesian aggregation scheme, with proper updates at the user side. Numerical results demonstrate strong performance of the method.

=𝔼​[θr,m]+cov​(θr,m,θ~r,m)var​(θ~r,m)​(θ~r,m−𝔼​[θ~r,m]).absent𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝜃𝑟𝑚covsuperscript𝜃𝑟𝑚superscript~𝜃𝑟𝑚varsuperscript~𝜃𝑟𝑚superscript~𝜃𝑟𝑚𝔼delimited-[]superscript~𝜃𝑟𝑚\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}[\theta^{r,m}]+\frac{\text{cov}(\theta^{r,m},\tilde{\theta}^{r,m})}{\text{var}(\tilde{\theta}^{r,m})}(\tilde{\theta}^{r,m}-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\theta}^{r,m}]). (33)

We next compute the required components:

By plugging the above components in (B), we obtain (14).

Proof of Proposition 1: By utilizing again the fact that the elements of 𝜽irsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑟{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r} are independent and θr,msuperscript𝜃𝑟𝑚\theta^{r,m} and θ~r,msuperscript~𝜃𝑟𝑚\tilde{\theta}^{r,m} are jointly Gaussian, we have:

Appendix E Proof of Theorem 3

With the same definitions as in Appendix D (and this time we adopt the convention that the summations of the user index are always over i∈𝒮r𝑖superscript𝒮𝑟i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}) we compose the error into three terms:

+𝔼​[‖𝜽^r−𝜽^r−1‖2].𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript^𝜽𝑟superscript^𝜽𝑟12\displaystyle+\mathbb{E}[||\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r}-\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r-1}||^{2}]. (50)

+2​η~23​𝒞r−1.2superscript~𝜂23superscript𝒞𝑟1\displaystyle+\frac{2\tilde{\eta}^{2}}{3}\mathcal{C}^{r-1}. (56)

The same arguments used in proving Theorem 2 can now be applied to prove the theorem.
